head.title: Gingrich Bids Farewell to Friends and Supporters and Hosts a Town Meeting

hedline.hl1: Gingrich Bids Farewell to Friends and Supporters and Hosts a Town Meeting

abstract.p: Speaker Newt Gingrich plays host to a farewell town hall meeting in Marietta, Ga, where dozens of people line up to offer effusive tributes to him and seething denunciations of Pres Clinton; maintains his distance from the details of impeachment process in House, which he has bequeathed to his successor, Rep Bob Livingston; photo (M)

As his colleagues in Washington debated President Clinton's fate, Speaker Newt Gingrich played host to a farewell town hall meeting in his district today that combined effusive tributes for Mr. Gingrich with seething denunciations of Mr. Clinton.

At both his forum at Walton High School and at a news conference, Mr. Gingrich maintained his distance from the details of the impeachment process in the House, which he has bequeathed to his successor, Representative Bob Livingston, and to Representative Henry J. Hyde, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee. He relented to speak about Mr. Clinton only when Chris Bennett, a ninth grader at Lassiter High School, asked him what the next President should do ''to restore dignity to the office.''

Mr. Gingrich responded: ''I suspect every person in this room is a sinner. But there is an enormous difference between being human and failing to recognize the responsibilities and the duties you have voluntarily accepted. I hope that the next President, whoever they are and of whatever party, takes seriously being the leader of a free people, takes seriously being commander in chief, takes seriously that the Oval Office is the civic center of the American nation. And I think, frankly, any reasonable person who takes those three and does them will in a heartbeat, will in the opening 24 hours, restore to the White House the dignity, the honor, the decency which it has so clearly lost in the last six years.''

At the town hall meeting, the 33d such forum that Mr. Gingrich has held in his district since becoming Speaker in 1995, dozens of the 500 people present lined up to pay homage. They hailed Mr. Gingrich, who will leave the House on Jan. 3, as a compassionate visionary who made time for his constituents even after the Republicans took control of the House in 1994. With thunderous ovations, they urged him to run for President, which he later said he would not do in 2000.

Mr. Gingrich, who announced his resignation from the House last month after the Democrats gained seats in the Nov. 3 election, said he had consulted on Friday with Mr. Livingston about next week's impeachment vote. But he refused to disclose any advice he offered about whether the Republican leadership should allow debate on a Democratic proposal to censure Mr. Clinton.

He urged all House members to vote their conscience. While declining to specify his own views on impeachment, Mr. Gingrich emphasized that his withdrawal from the House's leadership had removed a political obstacle to the proceedings.

''For the last month, because I haven't been public, because I haven't said anything, the focus really has been on some issues that are pretty important to the country,'' Mr. Gingrich said with a grin. He acknowledged that he is such ''a sufficiently vocal and polarizing personality'' that Mr. Clinton had been able to use him effectively as a foil. As long as he remained Speaker, he said, he would continue to serve as ''the excuse.''

''The President is a brilliant counterpuncher,'' Mr. Gingrich said. ''He does almost nothing positive but he hits those who try to do things remarkably well. And now, frankly, he has to stand on his own feet. He and Gore have to decide are they going to handle Washington, are they going to lead the world, are they going to solve problems. And the country will measure them without being in some kind of fight with the Republican Speaker of the House.''
After leaving the House, Mr. Gingrich, 55, said he would give paid speeches and remain vocal on issues.
